questions.question: What is the main difference in purpose between mitosis and meiosis?
options: Mitosis: growth/repair; Meiosis: gamete production
Mitosis: genetic diversity; Meiosis: somatic growth
Both processes are specialized for tissue regeneration
Both processes are specialized for sexual reproduction
questions.explanation: Mitosis produces identical cells for growth, repair, and asexual reproduction. Meiosis produces genetically variable gametes for sexual reproduction.

questions.question: How do the daughter cells compare genetically in mitosis vs meiosis?
options: Mitosis: identical; Meiosis: genetically different
Mitosis: genetically different; Meiosis: identical
Both result in two genetically identical diploid cells
Both result in four genetically unique haploid cells
questions.explanation: Mitosis produces two genetically identical diploid cells. Meiosis produces four genetically different haploid gametes.

questions.question: How many divisions occur in each process?
options: Mitosis: one division; Meiosis: two divisions
Mitosis: two divisions; Meiosis: one division
Both involve a single division of the cell nucleus
Both involve two consecutive rounds of cell division
questions.explanation: Mitosis involves one division of the nucleus. Meiosis involves two consecutive divisions (Meiosis I and Meiosis II).

questions.question: What happens to chromosome number in each process?
options: Mitosis: stays same; Meiosis: is halved
Mitosis: is halved; Meiosis: stays same
Both processes preserve the original diploid count
Both processes reduce the starting diploid count
questions.explanation: Mitosis maintains chromosome number (diploid -> diploid). Meiosis reduces chromosome number by half (diploid -> haploid).

questions.question: Where does crossing over occur?
options: Only in meiosis (Prophase I)
Only in mitosis (Prophase)
In both mitosis and meiosis
Neither process involves crossing over
questions.explanation: Crossing over (genetic recombination) occurs only during Prophase I of meiosis. This creates new gene combinations and increases genetic variation.

questions.question: How many daughter cells are produced?
options: Mitosis: 2; Meiosis: 4
Mitosis: 4; Meiosis: 2
Both produce 2 daughter cells
Both produce 4 daughter cells
questions.explanation: Mitosis produces 2 diploid daughter cells. Meiosis produces 4 haploid gametes.

questions.question: In which cells do these processes occur?
options: Mitosis: somatic cells; Meiosis: germ cells
Mitosis: germ cells; Meiosis: somatic cells
Both occur exclusively within the somatic tissues
Both occur exclusively within the reproductive organs
questions.explanation: Mitosis occurs in somatic (body) cells throughout the organism. Meiosis occurs only in germ cells (in gonads) to produce gametes.

questions.question: Which process creates genetic variation?
options: Meiosis creates variation; mitosis does not
Mitosis creates variation; meiosis does not
Both create significant genetic variation
Neither creates any form of genetic variation
questions.explanation: Meiosis creates genetic variation through crossing over and independent assortment. Mitosis produces identical copies, maintaining genetic consistency in tissues.

questions.question: How do the starting and ending cells compare?
options: Mitosis: diploid -> diploid; Meiosis: diploid -> haploid
Mitosis: haploid -> diploid; Meiosis: diploid -> diploid
Both pathways result in diploid daughter cell pairs
Both pathways result in haploid daughter cell sets
questions.explanation: Mitosis begins and ends with diploid cells. Meiosis begins with a diploid cell and produces haploid gametes.

questions.question: Why is it important that meiosis reduces chromosome number?
options: So fertilization can restore the diploid number
To allow the daughter cells to divide more quickly
To ensure all chromosomes are identical in size
To prevent the cell from becoming too large to function
questions.explanation: If gametes were diploid, fertilization would produce tetraploid (4n) zygotes. Halving in meiosis ensures fertilization restores the normal diploid (2n) number.
